Jim, all - 

I bet it would be interesting to see oshigata presented side-b=
y-side of the very same sword, using Nagayama's method (which apparently il=
lustrates details in a very graphic way) and the traditional (realist) meth=
od.  One method "draws in" the detail that should be noted while the other =
method gives a very "true" illustration of the hamon, leaving finding and u=
nderstanding the subtle "detail" up to the viewer...something like that, an=
yway.

Ron
STL
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Jim Gilbert 
  To: n=
ihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Tuesday, July 01, 2003 11:32 PM
  Subj=
ect: Re: [nihontostudy] A different view...


  Tom,
  Any idea of how the =
oshigata are actually drawn?  Looks like mottled gray paper, the usual ink =
cake for the outline... opaque white pigment (gouache?) for the hamon?  Not=
 sure how the hada is drawn in other than by lots of sharp pencil work.  In=
teresting way of representing utsuri and antai.  Reality can be marked on p=
aper in many different ways.  I wonder if Nagayama-sensei's methods will ca=
tch on.  Certainly different.

  Jim



    Now playing on another channel.=
